# SANDEEP COACHING CLASSES ## LIGHT – REFLECTION AND REFRACTION ---
### 1. INTRODUCTION TO LIGHT * **Definition:** Light is a form of energy that enables us to see objects. It travels in straight lines. * **Nature of Light:** Light exhibits a dual nature (Wave nature and Particle nature). * **Speed of Light:** The speed of light in a vacuum ($c$) is $3 \times 10^8$ m/s. --- ### 2. REFLECTION OF LIGHT The bouncing back of light rays into the same medium when they fall on a polished, smooth surface (like a mirror) is called reflection. #### A. Laws of Reflection 1. The angle of incidence ($\angle i$) is equal to the angle of reflection ($\angle r$). $$ \angle i = \angle r $$ 2. The incident ray, the normal to the mirror at the point of incidence, and the reflected ray, all lie in the same plane. #### B. Image Formation by Plane Mirror * **Nature:** Virtual and Erect. * **Size:** Equal to the size of the object ($h = h'$). * **Distance:** The image is formed as far behind the mirror as the object is in front of it ($u = v$). * **Lateral Inversion:** The left side of the object appears as the right side of the image and vice versa. --- ### 3. SPHERICAL MIRRORS Mirros whose reflecting surfaces are spherical are called spherical mirrors. #### A. Types 1. **Concave Mirror:** The reflecting surface is curved **inwards**. It converges light rays (Converging Mirror). 2. **Convex Mirror:** The reflecting surface is curved **outwards**. It diverges light rays (Diverging Mirror). #### B. Important Terminology * **Pole ($P$):** The center of the reflecting surface of a spherical mirror. * **Center of Curvature ($C$):** The center of the sphere of which the reflecting surface is a part. * **Radius of Curvature ($R$):** The distance between the Pole ($P$) and the Center of Curvature ($C$). * **Principal Axis:** The straight line passing through the Pole and the Center of Curvature. * **Principal Focus ($F$):** * *Concave:* The point on the principal axis where rays parallel to the axis converge. * *Convex:* The point on the principal axis where rays parallel to the axis appear to diverge from. * **Focal Length ($f$):** The distance between the Pole ($P$) and the Principal Focus ($F$). * **Relationship between $R$ and $f$:** $$ R = 2f $$ --- ### 4. IMAGE FORMATION BY SPHERICAL MIRRORS #### A. Rules for Ray Diagrams 1. **Ray parallel to Principal Axis:** Passes through Focus ($F$) (concave) or appears to diverge from $F$ (convex) after reflection. 2. **Ray passing through Focus ($F$):** Becomes parallel to the Principal Axis after reflection. 3. **Ray passing through Center of Curvature ($C$):** Retraces the same path (reflected back along the same line) because it strikes the mirror normally ($90^\circ$). 4. **Ray incident obliquely at Pole ($P$):** Reflected obliquely making equal angles ($\angle i = \angle r$). #### B. Image Formation by Concave Mirror | Position of Object | Position of Image | Size of Image | Nature of Image | | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | | At Infinity | At Focus ($F$) | Highly diminished (point size) | Real and Inverted | | Beyond $C$ | Between $F$ and $C$ | Diminished | Real and Inverted | | At $C$ | At $C$ | Same size | Real and Inverted | | Between $C$ and $F$ | Beyond $C$ | Enlarged | Real and Inverted | | At $F$ | At Infinity | Highly Enlarged | Real and Inverted | | Between $P$ and $F$ | Behind the mirror | Enlarged | **Virtual and Erect** | #### C. Image Formation by Convex Mirror | Position of Object | Position of Image | Size of Image | Nature of Image | | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | | At Infinity | At Focus ($F$) behind mirror | Highly diminished (point size) | Virtual and Erect | | Between Infinity and $P$ | Between $P$ and $F$ behind mirror | Diminished | Virtual and Erect | --- ### 5. USES OF SPHERICAL MIRRORS #### Concave Mirrors 1. **Torches, Searchlights, Headlights:** Source placed at Focus to get a powerful parallel beam. 2. **Shaving/Makeup Mirrors:** Face placed between $P$ and $F$ to see an enlarged, erect image. 3. **Dentists:** To see large images of teeth. 4. **Solar Furnaces:** To concentrate sunlight at a point to produce heat. #### Convex Mirrors 1. **Rear-view Mirrors in Vehicles:** They always give an erect image and have a wider field of view (curved outwards). 2. **Security Mirrors:** In shops (to view large areas). --- ### 6. MIRROR FORMULA AND MAGNIFICATION #### A. New Cartesian Sign Convention 1. The object is always placed to the left of the mirror. 2. All distances are measured from the Pole ($P$). 3. Distances measured in the direction of incident light are **Positive (+)**. 4. Distances measured against the direction of incident light are **Negative (-)**. 5. Heights upwards (above axis) are **Positive (+)**; downwards are **Negative (-)**. * **Concave Mirror $f$:** Negative ($-$) * **Convex Mirror $f$:** Positive ($+$) #### B. Mirror Formula $$ \frac{1}{v} + \frac{1}{u} = \frac{1}{f} $$ * $u$ = Object distance * $v$ = Image distance * $f$ = Focal length #### C. Magnification ($m$) Ratio of height of image ($h'$) to height of object ($h$). $$ m = \frac{\text{Height of image }(h')}{\text{Height of object }(h)} = -\frac{v}{u} $$ * If $m$ is negative: Image is Real. * If $m$ is positive: Image is Virtual. * If $|m| > 1$: Image is Magnified. * If $|m| < 1$: Image is Diminished. --- ### 7. REFRACTION OF LIGHT The bending of light when it travels from one transparent medium to another is called refraction. * **Cause:** Change in speed of light in different media. * **Rare to Denser:** Light bends **towards** the normal. * **Denser to Rare:** Light bends **away** from the normal. #### A. Refraction through a Rectangular Glass Slab * The emergent ray is parallel to the incident ray but laterally displaced. * **Lateral Displacement:** The perpendicular distance between the incident ray and the emergent ray. #### B. Laws of Refraction 1. The incident ray, the refracted ray, and the normal to the interface of two transparent media at the point of incidence, all lie in the same plane. 2. **Snell’s Law:** The ratio of the sine of the angle of incidence to the sine of the angle of refraction is a constant for the light of a given color and for the given pair of media. $$ \frac{\sin i}{\sin r} = \text{constant} $$ #### C. Refractive Index ($n$) * **Absolute Refractive Index ($n_m$):** Ratio of speed of light in vacuum/air ($c$) to speed of light in medium ($v$). $$ n_m = \frac{c}{v} $$ * **Relative Refractive Index ($n_{21}$):** Refractive index of medium 2 with respect to medium 1. $$ n_{21} = \frac{\text{Speed of light in medium 1 } (v_1)}{\text{Speed of light in medium 2 } (v_2)} $$ * **Example:** Refractive index of water ($\ce{H2O}$) is 1.33. This means the speed of light in air is 1.33 times the speed of light in water. * **Optical Density:** Higher refractive index = Optically denser medium (Light travels slower). --- ### 8. SPHERICAL LENSES A transparent material bound by two surfaces, of which one or both surfaces are spherical. #### A. Types 1. **Convex Lens:** Thicker at the center, thinner at edges. Converging lens. 2. **Concave Lens:** Thinner at the center, thicker at edges. Diverging lens. #### B. Important Terminology * **Optical Center ($O$):** The central point of the lens. * **Principal Axis:** Line passing through the centers of curvature of the two spherical surfaces. * **Principal Focus:** Lenses have two foci, represented as $F_1$ and $F_2$. * **2F:** Represents the center of curvature (double the focal length). Notation used: $2F_1$ and $2F_2$. --- ### 9. IMAGE FORMATION BY LENSES #### A. Rules for Ray Diagrams 1. **Ray parallel to Principal Axis:** Passes through the Focus ($F_2$) on the other side (Convex) or appears to diverge from Focus ($F_1$) on the same side (Concave). 2. **Ray passing through Focus ($F_1$):** Emerges parallel to the principal axis. 3. **Ray passing through Optical Center ($O$):** Passes without any deviation. #### B. Image Formation by Convex Lens | Position of Object | Position of Image | Size of Image | Nature of Image | | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | | At Infinity | At $F_2$ | Point sized | Real and Inverted | | Beyond $2F_1$ | Between $F_2$ and $2F_2$ | Diminished | Real and Inverted | | At $2F_1$ | At $2F_2$ | Same size | Real and Inverted | | Between $F_1$ and $2F_1$ | Beyond $2F_2$ | Enlarged | Real and Inverted | | At $F_1$ | At Infinity | Highly Enlarged | Real and Inverted | | Between $F_1$ and $O$ | On the same side as object | Enlarged | **Virtual and Erect** | #### C. Image Formation by Concave Lens | Position of Object | Position of Image | Size of Image | Nature of Image | | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | | At Infinity | At $F_1$ | Point sized | Virtual and Erect | | Between Infinity and $O$ | Between $F_1$ and $O$ | Diminished | Virtual and Erect | --- ### 10. LENS FORMULA, MAGNIFICATION, AND POWER #### A. Sign Convention (Lenses) * **Optical Center ($O$)** is the origin. * **Convex Lens $f$:** Positive ($+$) * **Concave Lens $f$:** Negative ($-$) #### B. Lens Formula $$ \frac{1}{v} - \frac{1}{u} = \frac{1}{f} $$ *(Note the negative sign, unlike the mirror formula)* #### C. Magnification ($m$) $$ m = \frac{h'}{h} = \frac{v}{u} $$ *(Note: For lenses, $v/u$ is positive)* #### D. Power of a Lens ($P$) The degree of convergence or divergence of light rays achieved by a lens. It is the reciprocal of its focal length. $$ P = \frac{1}{f} $$ * **Condition:** $f$ must be in **meters**. * **SI Unit:** Dioptre ($D$). * **Power of Convex Lens:** Positive ($+$). * **Power of Concave Lens:** Negative ($-$). #### E. Combination of Lenses If multiple lenses are placed in contact, the net power ($P$) is the algebraic sum of individual powers. $$ P = P_1 + P_2 + P_3 + \dots $$
